The beautiful, historic city of Santa Maria, CA is located about 65 miles northwest of Santa Barbara, 121 miles west of Bakersfield, and 159 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles. It is bordered by Guadalupe, Orcutt, Blacklake, Callender, Casmalia, Garey, Los Berros, Nipomo, Oceano, Sisquoc, and Woodlands.

Founded in 1874, Santa Maria was settled by Rudolph Cook, John Thornburg, Isaac Fesler, and Isaac Miller, whose names you‚Äôll see on local streets and school buildings. Santa Maria was officially incorporated as a city in September 1905 and was a major contributor to the oil industry during the 20th century. During the 1950s, more than 1,775 oil wells were operating in the area, though that number has significantly dropped since then.

The naming of Santa Maria is Spanish for ‚ÄúSt. Mary‚Äù and was attributed to the Californio ranchero Juan Pac√≠fico Ontiveros who owned land in the area.

Santa Maria is a good place to live and is known for its amazing wine industry and its distinct barbecue, which is cooked in a unique way.

Notable people who have lived in Santa Maria over the years include actress Kathy Bates, NFL football player Mark Brunell, musician Chris Lambert, and Olympic swimmer Josh Prenot.

You can determine the benefits of moving to Santa Maria as you learn interesting facts about what it‚Äôs like to live there and whether it‚Äôs the right place for you.

1. People Living in Santa Maria, CA ‚Äì Population & Demographics

How many people live in Santa Maria? There has been massive growth since the 1950s with over 100,000 people relocating to Santa Maria between then and now. The Santa Maria population is currently 107,273 residents with a median age of 29 years old.

Santa Maria demographics show the area‚Äôs vast Hispanic heritage as the population consists of 77.4% Hispanic, 59.4% White (15.1% non-Hispanic), 3% Asian, and 2% Black or African American. There are a bit more women than men living in Santa Maria with a sex ratio of 51% female and 49% male.

The median household income in Santa Maria is $69,393 per year, right around the US average.

Is Santa Maria a safe place to live? While the crime rate in Santa Maria is about 18% higher than the California state average, it is also 10% lower than the national average. Overall, residents feel that Santa Maria is a safe place to live with plenty of secure communities to choose from.

Locals are served and protected by the brave men and women of the Santa Maria Police Department, which has about 135 active duty police officers.

2. Cost of Living in Santa Maria, CA

The average cost of living in Santa Maria is about 19% higher than the national average but is also about 31% lower than the California state average, making it a more affordable option for the State. Compared to the state, local residents tend to pay less for groceries, utilities, transportation, and the Santa Maria real estate market.

4. Santa Maria, CA Weather & Climate

The Mediterranean climate in Santa Maria offers some of the best weather in the country, making it a highly desirable place to live. The weather in Santa Maria only gets about 16.5 inches of rain a year, leaving plenty of sunny days to enjoy. Bring your sunglasses!

The average temperature in Santa Maria during the hottest summer months is between the mid-50s at night and the upper 70s during the day. As winter approaches, the temp occasionally dips into the upper 30s in the evening, followed by highs in the upper 60 in the afternoon, so you may need a sweater or light coat.
